Maroc - Contribuer a une gestion durable

theme: Other public sector governance,Water resource management,Rural services and infrastructure,Urban services and housing for the poor,Pollution management and environmental health

abstracts.cdata!:
This brief shows that because of low
            rainfall and irregularity of distribution, water represents
            a social and major economic problem within Maghreb
            countries. Since independence, Morocco has strongly invested
            in building dams, developing water supply capacity to ensure
            coverage of water needs in urban and agricultural areas.
            Although mainly successful, this effort to develop supply
            was not accompanied by policies of compensation to ensure
            sustainable management, such as the management of water
            demand, conservation and protection of water resources and
            the development of equitable services for rural and poor
            communities. The brief spells out that water management
            strategies with regard to Morocco should therefore evolve to
            meet a number of challenges: growing water deficits,
            persistent gaps in access to services, slowness of the
            legislative changes, programs of limited infrastructure,
            population growth concern and climate change. Consequently,
            water was one of the essential priorities the Country
            Assistance Strategy established in Morocco with the
            International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
            for the period 2006- 2009.
